title: Retro TV Theme Songs
description: Can you match these iconic theme song clues to the right TV show?

questions.question: Which show's theme begins: 'Here's the story of a lovely lady who was bringing up three very lovely girls'?
questions.explanation: The Brady Bunch (1969-1974) had one of the most recognizable theme songs in TV history, describing the blended Brady family.

questions.question: Which show featured a theme song with the lyrics 'Just sit right back and you'll hear a tale'?
questions.explanation: Gilligan's Island (1964-1967) opened with 'The Ballad of Gilligan's Isle,' telling the story of the fateful three-hour tour.

questions.question: Which show's theme included the lyrics 'Making your way in the world today takes everything you've got'?
questions.explanation: The Cheers theme song 'Where Everybody Knows Your Name' by Gary Portnoy became iconic during the show's run (1982-1993).

questions.question: Which Western show's theme starts with 'Rollin', rollin', rollin''?
questions.explanation: Rawhide (1959-1965) featured the famous theme performed by Frankie Laine, later popularized in the movie The Blues Brothers.

questions.question: Which show's theme includes the famous 'dun dun' sound effect that became instantly recognizable?
questions.explanation: Dragnet (1951-1959) featured the iconic 'Dum-de-dum-dum' musical intro that became one of TV's most parodied themes.

questions.question: Which show's theme included 'Come and listen to my story about a man named Jed'?
questions.explanation: The Beverly Hillbillies (1962-1971) theme, 'The Ballad of Jed Clampett,' told the story of a poor mountaineer who struck oil.

questions.question: Which show began with the phrase 'Space: the final frontier'?
questions.explanation: Star Trek (1966-1969) opened with William Shatner's narration: 'Space: the final frontier. These are the voyages of the starship Enterprise.'

questions.question: Which show's theme song was 'Those Were the Days' sung by the cast?
questions.explanation: All in the Family (1971-1979) opened with Archie and Edith Bunker singing 'Those Were the Days' at the piano.

questions.question: Which show's theme promised 'We're gonna make our dreams come true'?
questions.explanation: Laverne & Shirley (1976-1983) featured the upbeat theme 'Making Our Dreams Come True' by Cyndi Grecco.

questions.question: Which show had an instrumental theme that featured a driving drum beat and horns, becoming the signature of 1970s cop shows?
questions.explanation: Hawaii Five-O (1968-1980) had one of the most iconic instrumental themes in TV history, composed by Morton Stevens.

questions.question: Which show's theme sang about 'movin' on up to the East Side'?
questions.explanation: The Jeffersons (1975-1985) theme 'Movin' On Up' celebrated George and Louise Jefferson's move to a 'deluxe apartment in the sky.'

questions.question: Which show featured the William Tell Overture as its theme music?
questions.explanation: The Lone Ranger (1949-1957) used Rossini's William Tell Overture as its iconic theme, becoming forever linked with the masked hero.

questions.question: Which show's theme included 'Love, exciting and new, come aboard, we're expecting you'?
questions.explanation: The Love Boat (1977-1987) had the romantic theme song performed by Jack Jones that became a pop culture staple.

questions.question: Which show opened with a narrator saying 'You are about to enter another dimension'?
questions.explanation: The Twilight Zone (1959-1964) featured Rod Serling's memorable narration and the eerie 'do-do-do-do' theme by Marius Constant.

questions.question: Which show had a theme that included 'Sunday, Monday, Happy Days'?
questions.explanation: Happy Days (1974-1984) featured the theme 'Happy Days' by Pratt & McClain, though it originally used 'Rock Around the Clock.'

questions.question: Which show's theme featured a catchy bass line and was performed by Quincy Jones?
questions.explanation: Sanford and Son (1972-1977) featured the memorable 'The Streetbeater' theme by Quincy Jones with its distinctive bass guitar riff.

questions.question: Which show's theme included 'Believe it or not, I'm walking on air'?
questions.explanation: The Greatest American Hero (1981-1983) featured 'Believe It or Not' by Joey Scarbury, which became a top-3 hit.

questions.question: Which show featured whistling in its theme and was set in a small North Carolina town?
questions.explanation: The Andy Griffith Show (1960-1968) featured the iconic whistled theme 'The Fishin' Hole,' with Andy and Opie walking to the fishing hole.

questions.question: Which show's theme began with 'Boy, the way Glenn Miller played'?
questions.explanation: All in the Family's 'Those Were the Days' began with nostalgic references to Glenn Miller's music and simpler times.

questions.question: Which war-themed show had a theme song called 'Suicide Is Painless'?
questions.explanation: M*A*S*H (1972-1983) used an instrumental version of 'Suicide Is Painless,' originally written for the 1970 film by Johnny Mandel.
